newsitem.title: UK: Firmer crude helps high but not low sulpur fuel oi.
newsitem.headline: Firmer crude helps high but not low sulpur fuel oi.

text.p: Firmer crude helped propel high sulphur cracked fuel oil up $2, but low sulphur was unable to capitalise because of long positions, traders said on Tuesday.
Good bunker demand helped push barge prices several dollars higher with early deals done at $123 fob ARA, ($124 fob Rotterdam). Prices eased in the afternoon with to peg barges around $120-121 fob.
Bunker demand was estimated as high as 30,000 tonnes.
"There's been a lot of volume and I think we may have stronger numbers again tomorrow as people try and cover themselves over Christmas," said one barge trader.
The high sulphur cargo market rose up on the back of barges to about $116-118 cif NWE, but activity was quiet.
"It's not tight, but it's not exactly awash," said one player who had secured product last week.

The low sulphur market took little comfort from Electricite de France's tender to buy 36,000 tonnes for January. "It's split up into little parcels - 10kt here, 25kt there, 5kt down there," said one trader, adding "It's too fragemented to give support." An early Jan 25kt cargo was heard offered at $127.50 fob NWE while a 45-50kt end month cargo was looking for $130 fob NWE.
